results.8-9:
Stone Covering
Requires Extended Hard (-20) Strength Test to a total of 10 SL to move. Fumbles during the Test result in a @Condition[Fatigued] Condition.
results.10-10:
Heavy Stone Covering
Requires Extended Very Hard (-30) Strength Test to a total of 15 SL to move. Fumbles during the Test result in a @Condition[Fatigued] Condition.

results.3-3: Forsaken by MorrAny @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.Item.PFTD9gDvRWW9uh5g]{Undead} creatures encountered in the tomb resist final death and possess the @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.Item.SfUUdOGjdYpr3KSR]{Regenerate} Trait.
results.4-4: SarcophagusAnything of value in the tomb is contained in a sarcophagus.
results.5-5: Submerged ChamberTo acquire any available loot, a Character must pass an Extended Hard (-20) Swim Test to a total of 15 SL.
results.6-6: Giant RatsA family of six @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.actors.Actor.oenbbB0PitRWUBfZ]{Giant Rats} make their home within the tomb and will attack any intruders.
results.7-7: Freezing AirThe temperature in the tomb is unnaturally cold. Characters entering the tomb must immediately test for @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.journals.JournalEntry.NS3YGlJQxwTggjRX.JournalEntryPage.WCivInLZrqEtZzF4#exposure]{exposure} to cold.
results.8-8: Rockfall TrapA trap has been set whereby rocks will fall on any Characters treading on a loose paving slab. Each member of the party must take a Challenging (+0) Perception Test. The first Character to fail is struck and takes [[/r 1d10]] Damage to the Head modified by Armour Points and Toughness.
results.9-9: Yellow MouldA patch of Yellow Mould is spotted on an Easy (+20) Lore (Plants) or Challenging (+0) Lore (Herbs) Test. Characters can avoid triggering the mould on an Average (+20) Stealth Test. If triggered, it releases a cloud of spores 5 yards wide which lasts [[/r 1d10]] Rounds. Characters in the area must pass an Average (+20) Endurance Test or gain 1 @Condition[Blinded] Condition, plus a further 1 @Condition[Blinded] Condition per –SL. Characters receive 1 Wound for every round spent in the cloud.
results.10-10: Labyrinthine PassagewaysTo reach the main burial chamber the Characters must navigate a network of passages. Finding a way through requires an Extended Challenging (+0) Navigation Test to a total of 20 SL. Any fumbles result in the Characters returning to the entrance and having to start again.

results.1-1: None
results.2-2: [[/r d10]]{D10} Goblins
results.9-9: [[/r d10]]{D10} Skeletons and a Banshee
results.10-10: [[/r d10]]{D10} Skeletons and a Cairn Wraith

results.5-6: A horde of ancient coins worth [[/r 2d10]]{2D10} GC.
results.7-7: Rusted swords and armour of historical interest, but no real value.
results.8-8: A bulky item such as a marble statue or golden ornament, worth [[/r 3d10]]{3D10} GC, but with 4 Enc.
results.9-9: A collection of weapons including 4 spears, 4 swords, and 4 shields. The items are of archaic design and well preserved, with the @Property[Fine] Quality.
results.10-10: Magical items, either a @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-archives2.journals.JournalEntry.hCDofMZ5QV2Y7z6r.JournalEntryPage.0X79eVjQ8MsvKiY2]{weapon} or [[/r d10]]{1D10} @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-wom.journals.JournalEntry.x6OdswRIafU9qGYs.JournalEntryPage.4k3qbP7drfV1mIdr]{potions}.

Bawd Income Endeavour Complications.name: Complicaciones en Empresa de salario de Chalán

results.1-1: Deuda Mayor. No has sabido ser discreto. Quizá un cliente adinerado fue expuesto mientras estaba a tu cargo, o cotilleaste demasiado sobre un pez gordo local. Ahora debes a esa persona un Favor Mayor.
results.2-2: Chantaje. Has recibido una carta que amenaza con revelar información comprometedora sobre ti o tus clientes a menos que pagues 2co en el próximo periodo de inactividad. Cómo pagar, si el escritor tiene realmente la información y cómo rastrearlo queda a discreción del DJ.
results.3-4: Amigo en los bajos fondos. Se te acerca un Perista que trabaja para una organización criminal. Necesitan un comprador para contrabando. Si puedes ayudar antes del próximo periodo de inactividad, podrían darte una parte del beneficio.
results.5-6: Rumor. Oyes un rumor sobre una oportunidad o un timo que funcionó en una ciudad extranjera y aún no se ha probado aquí. Los detalles quedan al DJ, pero hay ideas en @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-dslf.journals.JournalEntry.Irryfr7EthG42fzj.JournalEntryPage.XpxqHzvxCAr35b9R#rumores-de-los-bajos-fondos]{Rumores de los bajos fondos}.
results.7-8: Deuda. Has ganado la antipatía de un cliente. Puede cobrarte un Favor Moderado con el tiempo, como precio por tu descuido.
results.9-9: Contacto. Moverte por los bajos fondos te ha puesto en contacto con alguien que podría ser importante. Si realizas la Empresa de Contactos en este periodo de inactividad, cualquier Chequeo que hagas durante dicha Empresa obtiene +1 NE.
results.10-10: Amigo en las Altas Esferas. Atiendes a un personaje importante que quiere darse un paseo por los arrabales, quizá una condesa o un lector del culto de Sigmar. Puede que desee entregarse a un vicio que lo comprometería ante sus pares. Cumples bien tu papel y, como resultado, estableces una relación amistosa con esa persona.

results.1-1: Fraudster: Probably not dangerous but might be hard to identify.
results.2-2: Murderer: Highly dangerous and hard to capture alive.
results.3-3: Robber: Easy to identify but hard to locate. Usually has accomplices.
results.4-4: Con Artist: Probably not dangerous but might have multiple disguises.
results.5-5: Burglar: Difficult to locate and capture. Skilled at escaping custody.
results.6-6: Arsonist: Often leaves clues. Possibly unhinged or politically motivated.
results.7-7: Poacher: Possible vigilante against noble. Skilled at wilderness evasion.
results.8-8: Heretic: Might be a former initiate or cleric. Often has likeminded followers.
results.9-9: Mutant: Easy to identify; might have fled to a hidden mutant colony.
results.10-10: Cultist: Possible witch or sorcerer; hard to track and probably has accomplices.

results.1-1: Outlaw wanted for interrogation. Must be alive. 5 GC.
results.2-2: Outlaw wanted as example to others. Dead or Alive. 5 GC.
results.3-3: Fugitive from justice. To stand trial for moderate crimes. Must be alive. 5 GC.
results.4-4: Fugitive from justice. To stand trial for serious crimes. Must be alive. 8 GC.
results.5-5: Fugitive from justice. To stand trial for heinous crimes. Must be alive. 10 GC.
results.6-6: Fugitive from gaol. Escaped punishment for moderate crimes. Dead or alive. 8 GC.
results.7-7: Fugitive from gaol. Escaped punishment for serious crimes. Dead or alive. 10 GC.
results.8-8: Fugitive from gaol. Escaped punishment for heinous crimes. Dead or alive. 15 GC.
results.9-9: Imfamous Outlaw Chief. Wanted dead or alive. 40 GC.
results.10-10: Notorious Bandit King. Wanted dead or alive. 80 GC.

results.1-1: Town Bailiff: Oversees town watch, and reports directly to issuing noble.
results.2-2: Verenan Judge: Issues the warrant personally, and hires only reputable hunters.
results.3-3: Town Magistrate: Issues the warrant personally. Sits on town council.
results.4-4: Local Noble: Issues the warrant for a crime committed nearby.
results.5-5: Visiting Noble: Issues the warrant for a crime committed abroad.
results.6-6: Roadwarden Captain: Can post wanted bills. Reports to issuing judge or noble.
results.7-7: Riverwarden Captain: Can post wanted bills. Reports to issuing judge or noble.
results.8-8: Watch Captain: Can post wanted bills. Reports to bailiff or town council.
results.9-9: Bounty Hunter General: A subcontract via guild or independent general.
results.10-10: High Priest: Temple court judge; issues the warrant personally.

Burglar, Pickpocket, Thief Income Endeav.name: Complicaciones en Empresa de salario de Saqueador, Carterista y Ladrón

results.1-1: Los ranaldanos toman nota. Un grupo local que venera a Ranald, el Merodeador Nocturno, se entera de tus andanzas. Podrían ser buenos aliados si respetas el código de Ranald, pero si los ofendes pueden confundirte con engaños y bromas pesadas.
results.2-2: En el punto de mira. Has atraído más atención de la que te gustaría. Aunque la Guardia de la ciudad está más por mantener la paz que por investigar delitos, el Culto de Verena patrocina investigadores dedicados. La próxima vez que entres en un periodo entre aventuras, se te aplica el Evento Bajo sospecha antes de determinar nada más.
results.3-4: Vetado. Aunque nadie logra que prospere una acusación, te ganas fama de ladrón. Comerciantes y taberneros deciden que no eres bienvenido en sus locales. El DJ decide cuántos lugares te vetan, pero al menos uno te cierra la puerta. En zonas con muchas tabernas, como la Calle de las Cien Tabernas de Altdorf, pueden vetarte en varias a la vez.
results.5-6: Hallazgo afortunado. Además de asegurar tus ingresos habituales, tropiezas con algo extra. Tira una vez en la Tabla @Table[contents-of-purse]{Contenido de una bolsa}.
results.7-8: Un favor pendiente. Crees que te has librado cuando te contacta alguien que deja caer que sabe a qué te dedicas. Podrá reclamarte un favor menor con el tiempo, a cambio de mantener tus crímenes en secreto.
results.9-9: El capo se fija en ti. Las noticias de tus actividades llegan al oído de un señor del crimen local. Suelen hacer una oferta sencilla: trabaja para mí o atente a las consecuencias. Consulta @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-dslf.journals.JournalEntry.Gu0AnsYIpyHxK27i.JournalEntryPage.CezQBybX47Mx7Fdt]{Crimen organizado} para ideas sobre capos.
results.10-10: Botín jugoso. Además de tus ingresos habituales, levantas un par de objetos más interesantes. Tira dos veces en la Tabla @Table[contents-of-purse]{Contenido de una bolsa}.

Charlatan Income Endeavour Complications.name: Complicaciones en Empresa de salario de Charlatán

results.1-1: Los ranaldanos toman nota. Un grupo local devoto de Ranald el Embaucador se entera de tus timos. Podrían ser buenos compinches si respetas el código ranaldano; si no, podrían señalarte como objetivo de sus propios robos y tretas.
results.2-2: Cliente trágico. Uno de tus clientes deposita demasiada fe en tus falsas promesas y se produce una tragedia. Tal vez confía en tu medicina milagrosa en lugar de recibir otra ayuda médica, o cree que un falso relicario lo protege del daño. La naturaleza exacta y sus consecuencias quedan al DJ pero, como mínimo, habrá amigos furiosos si descubren al culpable.
results.3-4: Cliente fanático. Uno de tus clientes está convencido de que haces milagros. Quizá se recuperó de la infección de un necrófago tras beber tu aceite de serpiente o tuvo un sueño profético al comprar tu colgante de cometa de estaño bendecido. Ahora te venera de forma embarazosa, te sigue y proclama tu genio. Cómo evoluciona queda al DJ: puede traerte más clientes o atención indeseada.
results.5-6: Rumor. Oyes un rumor sobre una oportunidad o un timo que aún no se ha intentado aquí. Los detalles quedan al DJ, pero hay ideas en @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-dslf.journals.JournalEntry.Irryfr7EthG42fzj.JournalEntryPage.XpxqHzvxCAr35b9R#rumores-de-los-bajos-fondos]{Rumores de los bajos fondos}.
results.7-8: Timo a largo plazo. Tus timos despiertan interés, pero los clientes van con cautela. Si actúas con cuidado y paciencia, puede merecer la pena. Esta vez no ganas dinero con la Empresa de Salario. Sin embargo, si en el próximo periodo de inactividad haces una Empresa de Salario y tiene éxito, obtienes [[/r 1d10]] veces la cantidad normal.
results.9-9: Posible compinche. Se te acerca un raterillo que insinúa que sabe a lo que te dedicas y quiere ayudarte proporcionando distracción. Si lo contratas, debes pagarle una señal de un chelín al inicio de los periodos entre aventuras. En el futuro, cuando hagas una Empresa de Salario, tira [[/r 1d10]]. Con 1–9, ganas un 20% extra gracias a su ayuda. Con 10, huye con todo el dinero.
results.10-10: Un pez gordo se fija en ti. Tus delitos han llamado la atención de un jefe de los bajos fondos. Si no cooperas, podría ponerte las cosas difíciles. Consulta @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-dslf.journals.JournalEntry.Gu0AnsYIpyHxK27i.JournalEntryPage.CezQBybX47Mx7Fdt]{Crimen Organizado} para ideas sobre cabecillas.

results.1-27: Things Are Quiet. There is no significant change in the Contact’s circumstances.
results.28-33: Lying Low. The Contact has quit their usual residence in order to escape the scrutiny of rivals or authorities. They are likely still in the same city or province, but effort must be made in order to track them down.
results.34-39: Complacency. The Contact’s heart isn’t in it anymore. Reduce their Quality of Service by 1 level.
results.40-44: Gang Takeover. Organised criminals pressure the Contact to work for them. If the Contact was already part of a gang they join a breakaway faction or a rival gang. Depending on the quality of their relationship, they may recommend the Characters as potential associates to the gang (whether the Characters like it or not).
results.45-48: Dubious Customer. The Contact takes on work for a customer who the Character may not wish to associate with. The identity of this customer is left to the GM, but it may be a member of a rival gang, a revolutionary sect, a necromancer, Chaos cultist, or a species that views humanity with hostility, such as the Skaven.
results.49-54: Hard Times. The Contact grows desperate for money, and may seek the Character out to borrow funds.
results.55-59: Sick. The Contact contracts @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.Item.UAwTqZ3hqNb7vq9s]{Itching Pox}, and may be a source of contagion for the next [[/r 1d10]] weeks.
results.60-64: Corrupting Influence. During their activities the Contact is exposed to a @Corruption[moderate]{Moderate Source of Corruption}.
results.65-69: Stakeout. Members of the watch or a rival gang are keeping an eye on comings and goings around the Contact. If the Character contacts them during this time, there is a [[/r d100]]{33%} chance that the meeting is noticed.
results.70-73: Religious Conversion. Whilst the Contact remains a rogue, they have a marked shift in attitude in their approach to crime. If they didn’t follow Ranaldan principles before, they might take them up, or they devote themselves to a revolutionary cause, or even begin to worship a darker power.
results.74-78: Out of Sight…. Unless the Character has been in touch with the Contact since the last time this table was consulted, the Contact assumes they have parted ways, and the Quality of their Relationship becomes one step less close, so a Contact with a Good relationship to the Character now has an Average relationship.
results.79-83: Jailed. The Contact is convicted of a crime, and spends the next [[/r 2d10]] months in gaol.
results.84-89: On a Learning Curve. The Contact pushes themself to improve. To represent their growth, they move one step down the Quality of Service column of the Quality table, eg. from Fair to Superior Quality.
results.90-93: Pastures New. The Contact has decided to move to a different town or city. They may have left secret signs at their old address explaining where they have gone, left news with mutual acquaintances, or simply vanished.
results.94-97: Going Straight. The Contact tires of the criminal life, and tries to find a lawful role in society. If the relationship between the Contact and the Character is good, the Contact may be tempted to perform services for the Character, but they will need to be talked into it.
results.98-100: Embroiled in Violence. The Contact is assaulted by rivals, and suffers a randomly generated Critical Wound. This may result in the death of the Contact.

results.1-3: Disgusting: The food is barely edible. Anyone wanting to eat will need to make an Average (+20) Endurance or not be able to stomach it.
results.4-5: Spoiled: The food is completely spoiled and if the party are to eat, more needs to be found and prepared.
results.6-7: Burned: All the food is completely spoiled, and if there are enemies anywhere in the vicinity, they should have a very good view of a billowing cloud of black smoke.
results.8-8: Food Poisoning: Everyone eating the food gets a number of @Condition[Poisoned]{Poisoned} Conditions equal to the level of failure of the test.
results.9-9: The Bloody Flux: Make an Easy (+40) Endurance or contract the @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.Item.herUmN51D9TiL2Vn]{Bloody Flux}.
results.10-10: Galloping Trots: Make an Average (+20) Endurance or contract the @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.Item.txeLd7R13qxSvmsr]{Galloping Trots}.

results.2-2: Inhumación prematura. ¡El cadáver no está muerto! Quien fuera enterrado solo parecía muerto por un sopor profundo o un episodio de catalepsia. Puede tener sentimientos muy encontrados sobre ser “rescatado” de su entierro prematuro por un criminal que vende cadáveres.
results.3-3: Cadáver que se agita. Los ritos de Morr no han sido del todo eficaces con este cuerpo. Esto puede implicar que el cadáver se manifieste espontáneamente como zombi si queda expuesto a una influencia corruptora, o si ocurre una Disfunción mágica en sus cercanías.
results.4-7: Bañado en Shyish. El cadáver está impregnado de Shyish, algo que quienes tienen Clarividencia perciben como una sombría nube amatista alrededor del cuerpo. Cualquier intento exitoso de lanzar hechizos del Saber de la Muerte a 8 yardas o menos del cadáver gana +1 NE. Este bonificador solo puede reclamarse una vez, sin importar cuántas fuentes cercanas estén saturadas de Shyish.
results.8-14: Rostro familiar. El cuerpo está en buen estado, pero puede resultar mucho más reconocible de lo previsto. Cualquiera que conociera a esta persona en vida no tendría problemas para reconocer su cadáver.
results.15-17: Cadáver hinchado. Aunque sean restos de alguien fallecido recientemente, se descompone con rapidez alarmante, hinchándose y desprendiendo un hedor nauseabundo. Si el cliente espera un cadáver “fresco”, no quedará impresionado.
results.18-19: Restos eviscerados. Alguien extrajo los órganos internos antes de que llegaras. Si el cliente espera un cadáver con vísceras intactas, quedará decepcionado.
results.20-20: Espíritu inquieto. Los ritos de Morr no han sido plenamente efectivos con este cadáver. Su espíritu puede regresar para atormentar al Ladrón de tumbas como un Espectro, que seguirá acosándolo hasta que el cuerpo reciba de nuevo un entierro respetuoso.

results.2-2: Necrarca. Un poderoso Vampiro, maestro de las artes nigrománticas, contacta con el Ladrón de tumbas a través de un miserable sirviente intermediario.
results.3-4: Engendro Infernal caníbal. Este cliente podría estar camino de convertirse en un Necrófago, pero quizá prefiera mantener bien alimentadas a esas criaturas por motivos personales.
results.5-6: Nigromante. Desea perfeccionar su dominio de la magia nigromántica y necesita un suministro constante de cadáveres.
results.7-9: Urdidor. Quiere utilizar un cuerpo con fines políticos. Puede intentar cargar un asesinato a un rival o aprovechar la noticia de una muerte al servicio de una causa.
results.10-12: Físico corrupto. Este cirujano busca comprender mejor el funcionamiento del cuerpo humano. Solo paga por cuerpos frescos y sin daños.
results.13-15: Erudito de dudosa reputación. Un académico polvoriento que pretende mejorar su conocimiento de la anatomía.
results.16-17: Fugitivo. Quiere usar un cuerpo para fingir una muerte y que él, un familiar o un cliente puedan empezar una nueva vida en otro lugar.
results.18-19: Mago enloquecido. Probablemente un Mago Amatista que busca cosechar Shyish, aunque también puede ser un Mago Dorado tras componentes alquímicos o una bruja necesitada de ingredientes para sus rituales.
results.20-20: Demonólogo. Aunque los sacrificios vivos son los mejores ingredientes para los pactos de demonología, sus seguidores emplean partes de cuerpos para favores menores.

results.1-4: Watch - Good Crooks And Bad Constables – The Watch has been taken over by a corrupt commander who has started muscling in on the organisation’s territory. To keep up, the Character must undertake at least one Income Endeavour during this downtime period but receives only 50% of the income. If they do not do this, they may not make any @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-dslf.journals.JournalEntry.Gu0AnsYIpyHxK27i.JournalEntryPage.oVncgdl1rKl1S1cx#maintain-influence]{Maintain Influence} or @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-dslf.journals.JournalEntry.Gu0AnsYIpyHxK27i.JournalEntryPage.oVncgdl1rKl1S1cx#organising-crime]{Organising Crime} Endeavours. The rivals remain an ongoing threat, and the next ‘Gang War’ result will involve them. Due to the support they can pull from legitimate Watch members, any Test made to oppose them will be Difficult (-20%).
results.5-8: Watch - Someone Must be Found to Pay for the Crime – The headquarters is raided by the Watch, forcing them to relocate to an older (and smaller) hideout. The organisation’s level for the purpose of @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-dslf.journals.JournalEntry.Gu0AnsYIpyHxK27i.JournalEntryPage.oVncgdl1rKl1S1cx#organising-crime]{Organising Crime} Endeavours is reduced by one level until three adventures have passed or the character re-purchases the lost level. If a ‘Gang War’ event occurs during this period, the rival gang/leader gains +1 SL on all Tests.
results.9-12: Watch - Criminals Become Victims of their Own Success – Due to a spectacular crime drawing attention, the Watch have begun a major crackdown. No Character can make @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-dslf.journals.JournalEntry.Gu0AnsYIpyHxK27i.JournalEntryPage.oVncgdl1rKl1S1cx#organising-crime]{Organising Crime} Endeavours until the end of the next adventure. In addition, characters with Criminal Careers may not perform the @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.journals.JournalEntry.gLDW6JBuoYuzCoya.JournalEntryPage.JX9ifRlgzzGrU2zh]{Income} Endeavour at all until the end of the next adventure.
results.13-16: Watch - Are you Sure this is a Legitimate Business? – The Watch have directed excisemen to investigate the organisation’s legal fronts. The Character must spend an Endeavour assisting the investigation or pay 10% of the Enterprise’s most recent @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-dslf.journals.JournalEntry.Gu0AnsYIpyHxK27i.JournalEntryPage.oVncgdl1rKl1S1cx#build-gang]{Build Gang} Endeavour Costs in non-compliance fees.
results.17-20: Watch - Keep it Quiet – Your latest score draws heat from the Watch. If you use the @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-dslf.journals.JournalEntry.Gu0AnsYIpyHxK27i.JournalEntryPage.oVncgdl1rKl1S1cx#organising-crime]{Organising Crime} Endeavour during this period of downtime you gain+50% to any resources you collect. However, you cannot use the Organising Crime Endeavour during the next period of downtime.
results.21-24: No Honour Among Thieves – One of your Character’s Trappings, whatever is most valuable and portable, is stolen. The Character may attempt to reclaim it in the next adventure or accept its loss as part of the cost of doing business.
results.25-28: Factionalism – A disillusioned member leaves to start their own gang. The member is replaced by the start of the next adventure; however, the new gang may become an ongoing threat, and the next ‘Gang War’ result may involve them. Due to past friendships within the gang, and knowledge of your operations, this rival receives a bonus of +10 to opposed Tests.
results.29-32: Market Jitters – The organisation’s source of income dries up, meaning it must select a new source of income. If this was the organisation’s only source of income, the organisation counts as a Level 1 every time it tries to Get Resource during this downtime, as it is working hard to establish new contacts and fresh lines of supply.
results.33-36: Time to Make an Example – A ‘customer’ can’t make his protection payment, or a gang member falls short on his take. The character can either ‘make an example’ of the individual, and until the end of the next adventure, the character gains +10 to Intimidate Tests, but -10 to Charm Tests, or show mercy, causing others to follow suit, reducing the criminal organisation’s level by 1 until the end of the next adventure.
results.37-40: Knock-on Effects – The gang’s activities unexpectedly cause a complication for the Character’s companions. Roll on the @Table[event]{Events} Table and apply the effect to a different random Character.
results.41-44: A Fortunate Friend – A Priest of Ranald has befriended the gang. This has caused members to forswear the use of violence and attempt daring heists. If the Character uses Get Resource they receive [[/r d10]] shillings per level rather than the usual amount. Alternatively, they may chase off the Priest, but doing so earns Ranald’s disfavour, and they lose 1 Fortune Point next session.
results.45-48: Our Man on the Inside – The gang gains a high-ranking informant in the Watch. This can be used to either negate a single future Watch Event or grant 2 additional SL on a ‘Gang War’ Test as the informant directs the Watch against the rival gang.
results.49-52: You Get What You Take – As part of the gang’s usual operations, they come upon an item of value that is highly illegal/heretical (the GM can decide the exact item). Obviously, the character can keep or sell the item, but alternatively, they can hand it in to the proper authorities, earning a degree of goodwill. Next time the character rolls a Watch Event, that Event may be rerolled. The Character must accept the result of the second roll.
results.53-56: Bad Bookkeeping – A problem with rogues is that they tend to skive off administrative tasks. The Character must spend an Endeavour catching up on all the duties that their underlings have shirked. This does not count as an Income Endeavour. However, your sheepish members are nervous around the Character for the next few days, and any Skill Tests the Character is required to make as part of their other Endeavours they receive an assist with, as their underlings rush to help out.
results.57-60: Keep Your Friends Close… – A visitor to the city offers his skills in return for the organisation’s permission to engage in activity in the city. The Character may perform a single Endeavour usually restricted to a specific Class, even if he is not of that Class.
results.61-64: Talent Is Forever – A gang member, proud of a remarkable feat of skill he pulled off in a recent heist, is eager to share his knowledge. One @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.journals.JournalEntry.gLDW6JBuoYuzCoya.JournalEntryPage.0T8zisBH3D082Ztw]{Training} Endeavour carried out by the organisation can be carried out at zero monetary cost. Alternatively, one Unusual Learning Endeavour can be carried out at half the monetary cost, but at Average Difficulty (+20%).
results.65-70: A Little Birdie Told Me – The gang gains an informant in a rival gang. This grants the Character +2 SL to any Tests as part of the next Gang War Event. After the war has concluded, the informant joins the gang permanently. If the GM wishes the Character may take this opportunity to create a new Contact.
results.71-75: Diversification – The Enterprise gains a new Source of income. Any successful attempts to Get Resource this period of downtime result in double the usual amount of money.
results.76-80: Fell Off The Back Of A Cart – A gang member lays his hands on a valuable item that he donates to the organisation. This can be any item of value up to the criminal organisation’s costs to grow to its current level.
results.81-84: Trouble for the Watch – Members of the local watch have been chastised. They may have inadvertently arrested a powerful noble or priest or had corrupt practices exposed by followers of Verena or Ranald. For a period of the GM’s choosing, but no less than a week, they err on the side of caution and turn a blind eye to petty crimes.
results.85-88: Gang War - He’s No Longer With Us – Another gang encroaches onto the territory. If the Character backs down, they may not make @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-dslf.journals.JournalEntry.Gu0AnsYIpyHxK27i.JournalEntryPage.oVncgdl1rKl1S1cx#organising-crime]{Organising Crime} Endeavours during this period of downtime. If the Character fights back, the number of Racketeers who turn up the next time the Character uses Get Muscle is reduced by 2, but the Character gains a +2 SL bonus to interact with local criminals, who respect them for taking a stand.
results.89-92: Gang War - Turning the Heat Up – A rival gang instigates an all-out war. Make an Opposed Challenging (+0) Intimidation Test against the upstart and record the result, adding +1 SL for each level of the gang. The war continues into subsequent downtimes: make a further test each downtime until one side achieves 10 SL. No @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-dslf.journals.JournalEntry.Gu0AnsYIpyHxK27i.JournalEntryPage.oVncgdl1rKl1S1cx#build-gang]{Build Gang} Endeavours may be made with the Enterprise while the conflict continues. If the rivals win, the Enterprise is disbanded. If the character wins, all “Gang War” results are ignored for the next 5 downtimes, during which any successful attempts to Get Resource benefit from a 50% increase to earnings.
results.93-96: Gang War - A Tempting Offer – A member of the Inner Circle, or an underling backed by mysterious sponsors offers to purchase the gang. If the Character and their co-investors accept, they lose control of the gang and they gain wealth equal to double the organisation’s most recent cost to grow. However, this offer is not a suggestion, and if the character declines, replace it with “97-00: Gang War – Regicide”.
results.97-100: Gang War - Regicide – A gang member, such as an underboss, makes a play for control, resulting in a bloody conflict that costs the organisation significant resources. Make an Opposed Challenging (+0) Intimidation Test against the upstart. If you lose the organisation’s level is reduced by one. Furthermore, no @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-dslf.journals.JournalEntry.Gu0AnsYIpyHxK27i.JournalEntryPage.oVncgdl1rKl1S1cx#build-gang]{Build Gang} Endeavours may be made with the organisation during this downtime.

results.2-2: Estaca. El cadáver ha sido atravesado con una larga estaca de fresno. Lo que ocurra si se retira queda a discreción del DJ. Cualquier Personaje que supere un Chequeo Muy Fácil (+60) de Sabiduría académica (Muertos vivientes) sabe que esto pretende impedir que el cadáver se alce de nuevo como Vampiro.
results.3-3: Papeles. El ataúd está lleno de papeles y no se halla cadáver. Los papeles pueden revelar prácticas comerciales corruptas, experimentos mágicos poco éticos, intrigas entre casas nobles u otra actividad que el DJ considere apropiada.
results.4-6: Fosa común. Has descubierto una fosa común, llena de quienes eran demasiado pobres para costearse una parcela. Debes comprobar si has estado expuesto a @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.Item.aKiuGzlVO51JvsjV]{La Peste Negra}.
results.7-9: Ropa de calidad. El cadáver viste una buena chaqueta por valor de 9cp y ropa bien confeccionada por valor de 5cp.
results.10-12: Peniques. Es tradición en el Viejo Mundo colocar dos peniques sobre los ojos de un cadáver para que pague su paso al reino de Morr. Robar esos peniques se considera abominable; puede agitar al espíritu del difunto y es una de las principales razones por las que la gente detesta a los Ladrones de tumbas.
results.13-15: Ajuar funerario rico. El cadáver lleva un abrigo por valor de 1co, ropa de calidad por 10cp, y varios anillos de oro de 4co.
results.16-18: Necrófagos. Al abrir la tumba, algo te sisea. Has molestado a un par de Necrófagos en su festín. No queda nada de valor.
results.19-19: Ajuar funerario suntuoso. El cadáver viste túnicas por valor de 4co, vestimenta suntuosa por 2co y joyas deslumbrantes por un total de 10co.
results.20-20: Persona notable. Igual que el resultado Ajuar funerario suntuoso, pero con un Chequeo Difícil (−20) de Sabiduría académica (Heráldica) reconoces el cadáver como una persona de importancia local que desapareció recientemente.

Fence Income Endeavour Complications.name: Complicaciones en Empresa de salario de Perista

results.1-1: Reclamaciones de devolución. Justo cuando crees que te has librado, un comprador regresa insatisfecho. Haz un Chequeo Complicado (-10) de Regatear o pierdes la mitad de tus ganancias.
results.2-2: Refugio comprometido. Si posees o usas un establecimiento para almacenar o vender bienes robados, la guardia local se entera y empieza a considerar asaltar el lugar. Si no lo solucionas, en el próximo periodo entre aventuras se aplica antes que nada el Evento Bajo Sospecha.
results.3-4: Mercancía caliente. Entre los productos que has movido hay un objeto buscado desesperadamente por quienes fueron robados. El DJ puede decidir que este hecho pase a formar parte de tus aventuras futuras.
results.5-6: Rumor. Oyes un rumor sobre una oportunidad en ciernes o un nuevo tipo de timo. Los detalles quedan a cargo del DJ, pero hay ideas en la tabla @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-dslf.journals.JournalEntry.Irryfr7EthG42fzj.JournalEntryPage.XpxqHzvxCAr35b9R#rumores-de-los-bajos-fondos]{Rumores de los bajos fondos}.
results.7-8: Contrabando. Uno de tus proveedores necesita quitarse de encima, rápido y sin preguntas, un lote de contrabando. Si accedes, puedes comprar cualquier objeto de la tabla @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.journals.JournalEntry.sLomXnc8R8518cWN.JournalEntryPage.4CBQ1HlTC7lj9bFy]{Drogas y Venenos} de la Guía del Consumidor por una cuarta parte de su valor habitual (así, una dosis de @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.Item.W4X1Jx8AN84yRPDx]{Saliva} que vale normalmente 1co 5cp ahora costaría 6cp 3pb).
results.9-9: Premio oculto. Un objeto contiene una bolsita o compartimento con tesoro escondido. Además de cualquier ingreso obtenido, puedes tirar dos veces en la tabla @Table[contents-of-purse]{Contenido de una bolsa}.
results.10-10: Objeto maldito. Entre el contrabando que has manejado hay un artefacto con el que preferirías no haberte topado. Podría implicar piedra bruja o energía mágica maligna y cuenta como @Corruption[moderate]{Exposición Moderada a la Corrupción}.

Grave Robber Income Endeavour Complicati.name: Complicaciones en Empresa de salario de Ladrón de tumbas

results.1-1: Acosado por fantasmas. Los espíritus inquietos se indignan por tus atrocidades. Cualquier Criatura Muerto viviente con el Rasgo de Criatura Etéreo que te encuentres hasta el próximo periodo entre aventuras gana además el Rasgo de Criatura @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.Item.aE3pyW20Orvdjzj0]{Odio (tu Personaje)}.
results.2-2: Shyish. Aunque probablemente no lo notes, el Viento Amatista de la Magia se arremolina a tu alrededor. No en cantidad suficiente como para afectar a la hechicería, pero quien tenga el Talento @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.Item.OEjUvJKi0xmBwbS2]{Clarividencia} puede percibirlo. Este efecto se disipa en el próximo periodo entre aventuras.
results.3-4: Cliente siniestro. Se te acerca alguien reservado y siniestro que podría tener trabajo para ti en el futuro. El DJ debería tirar en secreto en la @Table[creepy-customer]{Tabla de clientes siniestros} para inspirarse. Conviene recordar que cualquier cliente de un Ladrón de tumbas exige discreción extrema, sea un físico curioso o un nigromante diabólico.
results.5-6: Hallazgo afortunado. Además de tus ingresos habituales, consigues un premio extra. Tira una vez en la Tabla @Table[crypt-complications]{Complicaciones de la tumba}, ignorando todo salvo el botín que obtengas.
results.7-8: Un favor pendiente. Crees haber salido impune cuando te contacta alguien insinuando que sabe a qué te dedicas. Podrá exigirte con el tiempo un Favor mayor como precio por guardar silencio.
results.9-9: Malos sueños. Te atormentan pesadillas, quizá enviadas por el propio Morr. De aquí al próximo periodo entre aventuras, el DJ puede pedirte un Chequeo Desafiante (+0) de Frialdad una vez cada dos semanas. Si fallas, sufres el Estado @Condition[Fatigado]{Fatigado}.
results.10-10: Botín jugoso. Además de tus ingresos habituales, levantas un par de objetos interesantes. Tira dos veces en la Tabla @Table[crypt-complications]{Complicaciones de la tumba}, ignorando todo salvo el botín que consigas.

results.2-2: Trozo de piedra bruja. Guardado en un estuche forrado de plomo, la piedra es una Fuente de Corrupción Moderada y vale 3co.
results.3-4: Insignia de plata. La insignia muestra el símbolo de un culto profano o de un dios proscrito, como Khaine, Stromfels o alguno de los Dioses del Caos. Poseer este artefacto puede ser delito en sí mismo. Vale 6cp 8pb para el comprador adecuado.
results.5-5: Folleto sedicioso. Un panfleto que defiende ideales revolucionarios, como los poemas satíricos de los kloszowskitas de Altdorf, o las reformas sociales radicales propuestas por los Nuevos Milenaristas de Middenheim.
results.6-6: Documento misterioso. Este pequeño pergamino contiene algún secreto escrito con un cifrado complejo. Podrían ser notas de una organización de espionaje, como los Caminantes de la Niebla de Marienburgo, o un contrato de asesinato.
results.7-9: Polvo de la risa. [[/r 1d10]] dosis. También llamado @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.Item.jTFOrokjEHbi12rT]{Delicia de Ranald}. Cada dosis puede venderse por 18cp.
results.10-12: Mercancía caliente. La víctima posee un anillo de zafiro valorado en 5cp. Sin embargo, lo consiguió con malas artes, trapicheos o robo.
results.13-15: Insignia de plata. La insignia vale 6cp 8pb. Muestra el símbolo de una banda con marcadas tendencias violentas o criminales, como los Garfios o los Peces de Altdorf, y la gente puede odiar o temer a quienes exhiban tal afiliación.
results.16-17: Reliquia ósea. Aunque puede no ser más que un trofeo macabro, quizá estuviera destinada a un rito nigromántico.
results.18-18: Vial misterioso. Este pequeño tarro de vidrio contiene un líquido extraño. Podría ser solo un sorbo de aguardiente exótico, pero también podría ser una @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-wom.journals.JournalEntry.x6OdswRIafU9qGYs.JournalEntryPage.4k3qbP7drfV1mIdr#catalogue-of-potions]{poción mágica}.
results.20-20: Fragmento de Monolito. Estas grandes gemas contienen la esencia del alma de Elfos muertos. Si bien pueden ayudar en la navegación, los Elfos no confían en ellas en manos ajenas, aunque podrían recompensar a quien se las devuelva.
results.19-19: Vial de @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.Item.qfd01sggD9xbCuJY]{Loto Negro}. 2 dosis del veneno preparado para untarse en una hoja.

results.1-3: Simple Marker. Whilst the stone is impressive, it is really nothing more than an ancient boundary marker or ritual site. There is nothing peculiar about the stone.
results.4-5: Beastman Herdstone. The monolith is a profane artefact raised by Beastmen. Within 20 yards of the Herdstone spellcasters using the Lore of Dark Magic or any Chaos Lore benefit from +1 SL to Casting Tests and +1 SL Channelling Tests. During the evening there is a 10% chance that the stone attracts Beastmen visitors (a Beastman Shaman with [[/r 1d10]] Gors and Ungors as followers) who howl and bray throughout the night and make profane offerings upon it. They will not take kindly to the Characters interfering with their holy site. The Herdstone is a source of Minor Exposure to Corruption. More detail about Herdstones can be found in Winds of Magic.
results.6-6: Ogham Circle. The monolith is part of an ancient circle created by followers of the Old Faith long before the coming of Sigmar. Within 20 yards of the circle, spellcasters using the Lore of Life or Lore of Hedgecraft benefit from +1 SL to Casting Tests and +1 SL Channelling Tests. More detail about Ogham Circles can be found in Winds of Magic.
results.7-8:
Elven Waystone. The monolith is part of the network of stones set up by the Elves thousands of years ago to help channel excess magical energy to the centre of Ulthuan. Roll [[/r 1d10]] to determine what form of magical energy is channelled by the stone.

  • 1: Lore of Light,
  • 2: Lore of Metal,
  • 3: Lore of Life,
  • 4: Lore of Heavens,
  • 5: Lore of Shadows,
  • 6: Lore of Death,
  • 7: Lore of Fire,
  • 8: Lore of Beasts,
  • 9: Roll again to generate two Lores,
  • 10: Roll again to generate three Lores.

Within 20 yards of the Waystone spellcasters using the relevant Lore benefit from +1 SL to Casting Tests and +1 SL Channelling Tests. More detail about Waystones can be found in Winds of Magic.
results.9-9: Grave Marker. The stone marks the grave of an important individual from ancient times. A nearby entrance leads to an Ancient Tomb. See the @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-dslf.journals.JournalEntry.xq3g1ukhk4RFHNSF.JournalEntryPage.2leXDE9eGgGpVVlC#ancient-tombs] for more information.
results.10-10: Orc Totem. The monolith has been desecrated by Orcs or Goblins, decorated with crude carvings, and besmirched with dung. During the evening there is a 10% chance that the stone attracts a group of [[/r 1d10]] Orcs and Goblins who come to celebrate their victories and praise their gods. If the GM has access to Tribes and Tribulations, they will be led by a Shaman. They will attack any Characters at the site.

results.1-1: Retirement: Accumulate enough money to leave the criminal life.
results.2-2: Avoid Capture: Evade the authorities. Death before surrender.
results.3-3: Grand Larceny: Perform only the biggest heists. No minor robberies.
results.4-4: Organised Crime: Pursue ventures in smuggling, racketeering or fraud.
results.5-5: Political Resistance: Fight the ruling nobles, rouse a peasant revolt.
results.6-6: Build Camp: Fortify and expand their camp to a colony, establish a forest haven.
results.7-7: Legendary Status: Build a legacy that lasts for generations.
results.8-8: Rule Fiefdom: Become a bandit king, by usurping a king or claiming new turf.
results.9-9: Spread Mayhem: Disrupt the peace. Revel in victims’ fear and despair.
results.10-10: Dark Purpose: Win favour of a Chaos god or immortality by necromancy.

results.1-1: Petty Hooligans: Young and inexperienced. Easily routed.
results.2-2: Squabbling Crooks: No cohesion. Squabbles more than it robs.
results.3-3: Sneaky Brigands: Clever ambush tactics. Uses secret signs and decoys.
results.4-4: Jolly Companions: Jokes and merriment, members are friends.
results.5-5: Fearsome Raiders: Loots and burns farms and takes hostages.
results.6-6: Gentleman Robbers: Non-violent highwaymen. Only steals from rich travellers.
results.7-7: Shady Hoodlums: Loiters around inns and taverns staking out targets.
results.8-8: Crafty Swindlers: Uses fake identities for heists or confidence scams.
results.9-9: Roving Marauders: Travels the wilds robbing anyone they find.
results.10-10: Hardened Cutthroats: Kills innocents to avoid leaving witnesses.

results.1-1: Cautious: Avoids heavily armed targets, plans for every contingency.
results.2-2: Daring: Puts themself at risk, with daylight robberies on hard targets.
results.3-3: Elusive: Escapes the law with ease. Camp is well hidden and mobile.
results.4-4: Connected: Legal immunity through a deal with a noble.
results.5-5: Popular: Well-liked by outlaws, local peasantry, or even law enforcement.
results.6-6: Extravagant: Throws lavish feasts and parties, and spends loot on luxuries.
results.7-7: Reckless: Leaves tracks or evidence, outlaws are frequently arrested.
results.8-8: Disciplined: Imposes strict rules. Monitors loot closely and runs a tight camp.
results.9-9: Ruthless: Often resorts to murder. Kills their followers to set examples.
results.10-10: Dark Bargain: Deals with sorcery or ruinous powers. Band is a cult.

Outlaw Income Endeavour Complications.name: Complicaciones en Empresa de salario de Forajido

results.1-1: Bandit Casualty. One of your fellow Outlaws is slain or badly hurt in the operation. If you are merely a Brigand or Outlaw this has no effect, but if you are an Outlaw Chief or Bandit King it means a henchman has been hurt, caught, or slain.
results.2-2: Dangerous Neighbours. During your activities you hear of a group patrolling near your camp. These could be roving Orcs, a band of Elves seeking to protect the forest, or a determined Road Warden patrol. If this group isn’t dealt with you must move on and set up somewhere new before you can take more Income Endeavours.
results.3-4: Fugitive in the Woods. You perform the Income Endeavour, but to escape with your earnings you must spend time hiding out in the wilds of the Old World until the heat dies down. You may not partake in any other Endeavours during this period of Downtime.
results.5-6: Lucky Find. In addition to securing your usual income you make an extra find. Roll once on @Table[contents-of-purse]{The Contents of a Purse Table}.
results.7-8: Bandit King Takes Notice. Word of the Outlaw’s activities reaches the ear of a local Bandit King. This individual desires favours or financial contributions. If they aren’t paid off they may lead their forces against any bandit gang who operates in their area.
results.9-9: Bounty Hunter. A Bounty Hunter has taken up a warrant to bring you to justice, dead or alive. This hunter must be faced before the next period of Downtime. The GM could introduce them into the adventure at some point, making dealing with them an integral part of the plot. If they wish, the hunter could be faced by the outlaw Character alone before resolving events in the next period of Downtime.
results.10-10: Stand and Deliver. In addition to making your usual income you lift a couple of interesting items. Roll twice on @Table[contents-of-purse]{The Contents of a Purse Table}.

results.1-1: Contempt of Court: Failure to appear for trial, roll again for original crime.
results.2-2: Tax Evasion: Failure to pay taxes to the local noble or city council.
results.3-3: Debt Evasion: Failure to repay debt to a bank, business, or moneylender.
results.4-4: Theft: Major robbery (over 50 GC) or a string of petty thefts.
results.5-5: Murder: Killing in cold blood. If rolled again, it was multiple murders.
results.6-6: Arson: Burning down buildings. If rolled again, it was serial arson.
results.7-7: Major Blasphemy: Impious speech or action drawing the wrath of the gods.
results.8-8: Heresy: Speaking false of the gods or clergy publicly and for personal gain.
results.9-9: Perversion: Action belying corruption: bodysnatching, kidnapping, cannibalism.
results.10-10: Mark of Chaos: Physical mutation or evidence of witchery.

results.1-1: Basic Survival: Food, shelter, and sanctuary from the law.
results.2-2: Wealth: Gold & silver coin, jewellery, anything that can be sold for value.
results.3-3: Excitement: Danger and thrill of the chase, and narrow escapes from the law.
results.4-4: Freedom: Wanderlust and a lack of responsibilities. Sleeping under the stars.
results.5-5: Camaraderie: Campfire jokes and stories, to escape from the loneliness.
results.6-6: Wantonness: Alcohol, drugs, vandalism, or indulgences of the flesh.
results.7-7: Notoriety: Local or regional infamy, often appearing on wanted posters.
results.8-8: Vindication: Pardon by courts or revenge against judge, noble, or accuser.
results.9-9: Aspirant Chief: Usurp the chief or become chief of a new outlaw band.
results.10-10: Dark Secret: Undercover mutant, witch, heretic, necromancer, or sorcerer.

results.1-1: Furtive: Quiet and solitary, holding their cards close to their chest.
results.2-2: Idealistic: Opinionated and outspoken, but their ideas are rarely realistic.
results.3-3: Charming: Friendly and sociable, usually to acquire something they want.
results.4-4: Conniving: Always has a new scheme, and often tricks other outlaws in the band.
results.5-5: Resourceful: Has a solution for every problem. Useful contacts outside the band.
results.6-6: Loyal: Reports all rule breaches to the chief, good candidate for lieutenant.
results.7-7: Paranoid: Trusts nobody. Sleeps with one eye open and a dagger in hand.
results.8-8: Selfish: Disobedient or unreliable on jobs. Argues over loot sharing.
results.9-9: Uncouth: Dirty, vulgar, or unmannered. Causes problems with civilians.
results.10-10: Violent: Has anger or trauma issues. Snaps easily and uses excessive force.

results.1-1: Chilly. The Contact does not much like the Character. They work for them, grudgingly, but have particular feelings towards them beyond a source of occasional opportunities. If interrogated, they would give up the Character’s name to save their own skin.
results.2-3: Iffy. The Character can generally trust in the Contact’s information or services, but from time to time they prove unreliable. The contact has no warm regard for the Character.
results.4-7: Average. The bonds between the Character and Contact are dependable. The Character can trust the Contact, but they won’t risk themselves on behalf of the Character.
results.8-9: Good. The Contact is genuinely friendly towards the Character. They may even help out without the Character specifically asking for it.
results.10-10: Solid. The Contact regards the Character warmly. They will always try to help the Character out, and will never willingly betray them.

results.1-1:
Dreadful. The Contact’s services are of low quality. Information they provide may prove false, and their lockpicks shatter at inconvenient moments. If they’re a fence, they have trouble finding buyers for stolen goods. If they provide a safe house, that shelter is uncomfortable, and if they help to store a stash, that room may be flooded or burgled. The Contact is so inept that they might soon be arrested for their own crimes.

To represent their general incompetence, if the Contact is statted out, Tests they take suffer from a penalty of -2 SL. If not, take Tests on a score of 25.
results.2-3:
Poor. The Contact’s services are of mediocre quality. They are capable, but mediocre. The information they provide is mostly correct, but lacks detail. Equipment from contacts like these is practical, but imprecise. Forged documents and artworks pass a quick inspection, but are discovered as false by anyone who takes the time to look closely. The watch may already be suspicious of the Contact.

To represent their mediocrity, if the Contact is statted out, Tests they take suffer from a penalty of -2 SL. If not, take Tests on a score of 35.
results.4-7: Fair. The Contact’s services are fair. A forger of this level will produce forgeries that can pass a decent inspection, a fence pays a decent price for stolen goods, and any information they provide is broadly accurate.
results.8-9:
Superior. The Contact’s services are of superior quality. A forger of this level produces forgeries that pass close inspection, a fence is able to pay a premium for the goods sold to them, and information they provide is comprehensive.

To represent their general competence, if the Contact is statted out, Tests they take benefit from a bonus of +1 SL. If not, take Tests on a score of 55.
results.10-10:
Awesome. This Contact’s services are top-notch. Their information is accurate, and includes relevant information that hadn’t even been asked for. The equipment they sell is of superior quality. Their hiding places are secure, and luxurious to boot.

To represent their prodigal skills, if the Contact is statted out, Tests they take benefit from a bonus of +2 SL. If not, take Tests on a score of 65.

results.2-2: Witch’s Lair. A Witch is using the ruin as a hideout. Their abilities are left to the GM, but they should at least have the Channelling and Language (Magick) skills of [[/r 35+4d10]], 4 Petty Spells, and 4 Spells from the Lore of Witchcraft. The Witch is not necessarily hostile towards the Characters, but will be cautious with them, and quick to defend themself if they are not dealt with diplomatically.
results.3-3: Ruined Trading Post. The ruin was once a trading post but hasn’t been used for many centuries. If it is explored a Character who passes an Extended Challenging (+0) Perception to a total of 15 SL may find coins and trinkets to a total of [[/r 1d10]] GC.
results.4-5: Frontier Outpost. The ruins have recently been settled by a band of people looking to make a new life for themselves or exploit a local resource. They may be small scale farmers or shepherds, wood cutters, a Strigany caravan, or simply subsisting on fish and young bog octopi. These folk are likely insular and may represent a community with radical religious beliefs or political ideas. They are more likely to deal with travellers with chilly formality than overt hostility.
results.6-7: Snotlings. The ruins are infested by a band of [[/r 2d10]] Snotlings and the stench of their dung permeates the area. In daylight hours they are terrified of the Characters and hide from them rather than fight. At night, they become bolder and seek to creep into any nearby camp to steal food and shiny items. If they are confronted, they cannot be reasoned with and fight for their lives. If their den is discovered it comtains a selection of coins and trinkets worth [[/r 5d10]] Silver Shillings.
results.8-14: Rubble. There is nothing of note here other than a few piles of scattered stones.
results.15-16: Sound Structure. Amongst the ruins is a sound building that affords the Characters the opportunity to rest for the night. If the Characters stay here any Make Camp Endeavour beneifts from +5 SL.
results.17-18: Bandit Camp. The ruins house a band of 6–8 Outlaws. To determine how much loot they have in their possession roll twice on the loot column of the @Table[ancient-tomb]{Ancient Tomb Table}.
results.19-19: Trolls. The ruins are inhabited by a trio of Trolls. They have smeared the stones of the ruin with blood and filth and piles of bones and bits of battered equipment lie all around. Roll [[/r 1d10]]. 1–3: The Trolls are home and will fight the Characters unless provided with a creature of Size: Average or larger to eat. 4–5: The Trolls are starving, reduce Strength and Toughness by 20, all other Characteristics by 10, and Wounds by [[/r 3D10]]. 6–7: The Trolls are home and will fight Characters to the death. 8–9: The Trolls are absent, but each round there is a 3% chance that they will return. 10: The Trolls are absent. To determine whether there is anything of value in the ruin roll twice on the loot column of the @Table[ancient-tomb]{Ancient Tomb Table}.
results.20-20: Wizard’s Tower. These famed constructions do not necessarily need to be a tower, as different schools of wizardry are attracted to different types of terrain, and construct their dwellings in different ways. A Celestial Wizard is likely to dwell in a tall tower in the mountains, while a Jade one prefers a verdant glade deep within the forest. Many wizards prefer secluded locations away from mundane folk and the trivia of their everyday lives. Here they can get on with diligent magical research unhindered by the powers that be, and even the authorities of their own college. Although this is a reasonable aspiration, there might be a more nefarious reason behind their chosen isolation. Some wizards choose isolation to quietly follow the Dark Gods, or research methods of wielding proscribed power. These often pose with the trappings of more legitimate schools to help keep them from the suspicion of those who do stumble upon their dwelling. If the Characters do suspect a wizard of malpractice, then they may be better off keeping that to themselves. The Wizard’s college and abilities are left to the GM, but they should at least have the Channelling and Language (Magick) skills of [[/r 35+4d10]], 4 Petty Spells, and 4 Lore Spells. The wizard might view the arrival of the Characters as a good opportunity. They are likely to need something from civilisation, and it would be a great help to them if the Characters agreed to fetch it.

results.2-2: Algo incriminatorio. La víctima lleva un objeto valioso, pero es peligroso o incriminatorio, y el carterista quizá prefiera no tenerlo encima. Tira en la @Table[incriminating-artefact]{Tabla de artefacto incriminatorio}.
results.5-6: Sin blanca. La víctima lleva una única moneda determinada por su Estatus.
results.7-7: Juego de dados de hueso. Este par de dados vale 10pb.
results.8-9: Pañuelo de tafetán. Un fino pañuelo valorado en 1cp. Tira [[/r 1d10]]; con 5 o más, el objeto tiene monograma.
results.10-12: Día de paga. La víctima lleva el doble de dinero de lo habitual.
results.13-13: Anillo de plata con decoración de grifo. Esta joya vale 3cp.
results.14-14: Pañuelo de seda. Un fino pañuelo de seda valorado en 3cp 6pb. Tira [[/r 1d10]]; con 5 o más, el objeto tiene monograma.
results.15-15: Guantes de cuero. Un par de guantes bien hechos valorados en 4cp.
results.16-16: Anillo con rubí. Un anillo de plata engastado con una piedra preciosa roja valorado en 5cp.
results.17-17: Insignia de martillo de plata. Una pequeña pero intrincada insignia que declara la devoción del portador a Sigmar, valorada en 6cp 8pb.
results.18-18: Derrochador. Además de monedas por valor del doble del Estatus del dueño, añade otras [[/r 1d10]] monedas.
results.19-19: Frasco de perfume. Un pequeño frasco de vidrio con tapón de plata que contiene un líquido almizclado, valorado en 10cp.
results.20-20: Collar de perlas de Miragliano. Este collar es una ristra de perlas recogidas en el Mar de Tilea, valorado en 10cp.

results.2-2: Conocido previamente. La víctima reconoce vagamente al PJ, porque ya se han visto antes o ha presenciado sus andanzas. El grado en que conoce al PJ queda a discreción del DJ, y el PJ puede hacer un Chequeo Difícil (–20) de Percepción para detectar ese gesto fugaz de reconocimiento en su rostro.
results.3-3: Habilidad extraña. La víctima posee una capacidad extraña que complica robarle. Tal vez sea un augur con la habilidad @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-wom.items.Item.GxfrW2whVdNJABVQ]{Psicometría}, un vidente o un aprendiz de hechicero o bruja.
results.4-4: Amigos en los bajos fondos. La víctima tiene amigos en el hampa o paga por protección. A la chusma no le hará gracia enterarse de que su amigo ha sido víctima de un delito (del que ellos no sacaron tajada).
results.5-5: Miembro amputado. Una enfermedad o herida ha provocado la pérdida o inutilidad de una parte del cuerpo. Tira [[/r 1d10]]. 1–3: Pierna, 4–6: Brazo, 7–8: Ojos, 9: Lengua, 10: Orejas.
results.6-6: Bolsa señuelo. La víctima ya se ha topado con carteristas y lleva una bolsa llamativa con dos peniques. Las monedas de mayor valor van escondidas en el calcetín o la cinta del sombrero. Tira otro [[/r 1d10]]. Con un 1, el objetivo ha sido tan rencoroso como para dejar una aguja envenenada en la bolsa señuelo, infligiendo el Estado @Condition[Poisoned]{Envenenado} a quien la coja y falle un Chequeo Desafiante (+0) de Percepción.
results.7-7: Desprevenido. Te daría pena… si no te lo estuviera poniendo tan fácil. Sus Chequeos de @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.Item.Fs06sr7y9JKpVQmB]{Percepción} sufren un penalizador de –1 NE.
results.8-8: Intoxicado. La víctima ha bebido demasiada cerveza o ha comido Raíz extraña. Tira en la tabla @Table[stinking-drunk]{Borracho como una cuba} o aplica los efectos de @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.Item.b6tGqvNe1jYBdeN5]{Raíz extraña}.
results.9-9: Veterano. La víctima fue en su día un soldado estatal del Imperio. Aplica el Rasgo de Criatura @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.Item.9NROryHer1uXAKwY]{Elite}.
results.10-10: Tipo duro. Mejor no te metas con este fulano. Aplica el Rasgo de Criatura @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.Item.15ENOMf345S5AL68]{Bruto}.
results.11-11: Precavido. La mayoría en el Imperio sabe que los criminales se ceban con clientes desprevenidos en tabernas o birlan cosas de puestos sin vigilancia. Concede a la víctima un Punto de Fortuna que pueda gastarse para repetir un único Chequeo que evite que caiga víctima de un acto criminal.
results.12-12: Avispado. Esta víctima es serena y lista. Aplica el Rasgo de Criatura @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.Item.Ni4hNAPv3LhTpgMA]{Listo}.
results.13-13: Se encuentra pachucho. La víctima empieza a padecer la @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.Item.UAwTqZ3hqNb7vq9s]{Plaga picante}. Al acercarse a ella, el PJ debe superar un Chequeo Normal (+20) de Percepción para notar las ampollas reveladoras antes de aproximarse demasiado.
results.14-14: Futuro patrón. La víctima podría estar en posición de ofrecer trabajo al carterista más adelante, o de proporcionar ayuda o información vital en el futuro.
results.15-15: Está nervioso. Ganarle la mano a la víctima es complicado. Sus Chequeos de @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.Item.Fs06sr7y9JKpVQmB]{Percepción} se benefician de +1 NE.
results.16-16: Cortabolsas. La víctima también practica la ratería. Quizá el carterista acabe siendo robado a su vez.
results.17-17: Amigos en las altas esferas. La víctima puede no ser especialmente rica o poderosa por sí misma, pero tiene conexiones con quienes sí lo son. Tal vez sirva en una casa noble, o algo más exótico como ser el siervo de un Vampiro, un espía de otra nación o un miembro de una secta del Caos. Esto puede atraer a quienes busquen explotarla, pero también significa que podría hallar ayuda para resarcirse.
results.18-18: Vengativo. Esta víctima está muy motivada para vengarse de quien le robe. Cuando descubre que ha sido víctima de un delito, destina una sorprendente cantidad de energía y recursos a averiguar quién le robó y llevarlo ante la justicia. Los Enanos pueden considerarse así por defecto.
results.19-19: Enfermo. La víctima está en las primeras fases de @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.Item.aKiuGzlVO51JvsjV]{la Peste Negra} y llena de pulgas. Al acercarse a la víctima, el PJ debe superar un Chequeo Desafiante (+0) de Percepción para notar los síntomas y evitar un chequeo de contagio.
results.20-20: Mutante. La víctima es un mutante. Su mutación va oculta bajo la ropa, pero puede hacerse evidente para un carterista durante el intento de robo. Tira [[/r 1d10]]: 1–2: @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.Item.op4GKikIQee7JMXw]{Patas de animal}, 3–4: @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.Item.iLZcSRUbxKBecACZ]{Corpulento}, 5–6: @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.Item.dsYDcdQfJGc7wxSX]{Demacrado}, 7–8: @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.Item.u5lMTKaOsZfiE3p0]{Articulaciones adicionales en las piernas}, 9–10: @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.Item.ArCg0WaBxLgPQA8F]{Plumaje ralo}.

results.1-2: Attention Elsewhere. There are no Watchmen in the vicinity. If a hue and cry is raised it will take 20 minutes or more for a patrol to arrive
results.3-5: Round the Block. The nearest watch patrol is a few streets away. If a hue and cry is raised it will take 20 Rounds or more for a patrol to arrive.
results.6-8: Patrol in the Vicinity. There is a watch patrol within 100 yards of the location. If a crime is committed in a public area a Watchman may spot it on an Opposed Very Hard (-30) Perception/StealthVery . If a hue and cry is raised it will take 10 Rounds for a patrol to arrive.
results.9-9: Patrol Nearby. There is a watch patrol within 50 yards of the location. If a crime is committed in a public area a Watchman may spot it on an Opposed Difficult (-10) Perception/Stealth. If a hue and cry is raised it will take 5 Rounds for a patrol to arrive.
results.10-10: Patrol Present. There is clearly a patrol either in the same street, or right outside the location in question. If a crime is committed within their line of sight a Watchman may spot it on an Opposed Average (+20) Perception/Stealth. If a hue and cry is raised the patrol responds immediately.

results.1-1: Sweltering
results.2-2: Hot

results.1-1: Still
results.2-2: Light

results.1-5: Wilderness Event. Roll on the @Table[wilderness-travel-events]{Wilderness Travel Events Table 1 - Light Woodland, Hills and Temperate Plains}.
results.6-6: Bloodsedge Grove. The Characters wander into an area within which Bloodsedge bushes grow. These predatory plants grasp and strangle prey with their thorny branches. A Character can identify (and avoid) Bloodsedge by passing an Easy (+40) Lore (Herbs) or Challenging (+0) Outdoor Survival. If the GM has access to a copy of Lustria the rules for Grasping Creeper Vine could be used in place of Bloodsedge. Otherwise, the Characters must cross an area of [[/r 3d10]] Yards, making a Hard (-20) Dodge every Round they spend in the area. Any time a Character fails the Test they take a Damage 5 Hit to a randomly determined location.
results.7-7: Herbs. The Characters cross a glade within which valuable herbs grow. These plants can be identified by passing an Easy (+40) Lore (Herbs) Test. The herbs may be @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.Item.b6tGqvNe1jYBdeN5]{Weirdroot} or @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.Item.wgFj3lFhCuO8OeDb]{Moonflower} from the WFRP Core Rulebook, or any of the @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-dotr.journals.JournalEntry.JhZ4qkEf569rEcsY]{Herbs} described in the Death on the Reik Companion.
results.8-8: Spites. This area of the forest is plagued by @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-salzenmund.actors.Actor.WCg8r2VwNIRehLZJ]{Spites}. If the GM has access to Salzenmund: City of Salt and Silver they could use the rules presented there to represent the @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-salzenmund.journals.JournalEntry.jSPXWkAU3a9CI1FB]{Spites}. If not, each Character is unable to sleep soundly whilst in the area and must take a @Condition[Fatigued]{Fatigued} Condition that lasts until they make a successful @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-dslf.journals.JournalEntry.xq3g1ukhk4RFHNSF.JournalEntryPage.YF6OGH5E8oLTde07#recuperate-endeavour]{Recuperate Endeavour}.
results.9-9: Spiders. The Characters come across the lair of 4–6 Giant Spiders. Most of these creatures will be @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.Item.8slW8CJ2oVTxeQ6q]{Size (Small)}, but one will be Size: Large. The spiders will seek to attack and entangle the Characters and will fight to the death.
results.10-10: Enemies Encountered. A small group of enemies crosses the Characters’ path. In the forests of the Reikland suitable enemies may be tribes of Forest Goblins, a herd of Beastmen consisting of Ungors and Gors, or a band of Outlaws.

Wilderness Travel Events – Light Woodlan.name: Wilderness Travel Events – Light Woodland, Hills and Temperate Plains

results.1-1: Pathway Blocked. A lake, river, or gorge blocks the Characters’ path. It is impossible to navigate around using mundane means, so unless the Characters possess some means to fly over and engineer their way across, they must find another route, adding a further two stages to their journey.
results.2-2: Barrow. The Characters pass by a series of eerie standing stones surrounding a small hill. Any Character passing an Easy (+40) Lore (History) or Lore (Local) Test will recognise this as a barrow. See the Ancient Tomb Table (page 121) for more information.
results.3-3: Monolith. The Characters notice a large single standing stone or ancient circle of menhirs. See the page on @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-dslf.journals.JournalEntry.xq3g1ukhk4RFHNSF.JournalEntryPage.2leXDE9eGgGpVVlC#monolith]{Monoliths} for more information.
results.4-4: Ruin. The Characters notice the remains of old buildings as they pass by. See the page on @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-dslf.journals.JournalEntry.xq3g1ukhk4RFHNSF.JournalEntryPage.2leXDE9eGgGpVVlC#crumbling-ruin]{Ruins} for more information.
results.5-5: Ailing Animal. Randomly select one of the animals accompanying the party. This animal is ailing. If a member of the party passes a Hard (-20) Animal Care there is no effect. If not impose the penalties for a @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.Item.kKccDTGzWzSXCBOb]{Festering Wound} to the animal. If this result is generated a second time for the same animal, it passes away.
results.6-6: Worn Out Item. A piece of equipment suffers wear and tear. Randomly determine a Character and one of their trappings. If a member of the party passes a Hard (-20) Trade (Carpenter, Leather Worker, Tailor, or Smith) Test there is no effect. If not, a metal item gains the @Prop[shoddy]{Shoddy} Flaw or an item of leather, canvas, or wood falls apart.
results.7-7: Fellow Travellers. The Characters spot a band of fellow travellers ahead of them. These travellers may be avoided or approached. The travellers are a group of 4–6 Pedlars or Villagers. Use the @Table[victim-quirk]{Victim Quirk Table} to help determine how they might behave. For the profiles of the travellers, use the @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-dslf.actors.Actor.xOMceDSC4pxIjQcR]{Outlaw}.
results.8-8: Spring. Clear, fresh water bubbles from the ground. The party may replenish their stocks of water as if they succeeded a @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-dslf.journals.JournalEntry.xq3g1ukhk4RFHNSF.JournalEntryPage.w5XYNzkXObxeBzFD#water-endeavour]{Water Endeavour} with no need to test.
results.9-9: Animals Encountered. A pack of 6 wolves or pair of bears forage not far from the Characters. They are unlikely to make an aggressive moves against a group, but may trail the party and attack a straggler or stray pack animal.
results.10-10: Enemies Encountered. A small group of 4–6 enemies crosses the Characters’ path. In the hillsides, light woodlands, and temperate plains of the Reikland suitable enemies may be tribes of Goblins, herds of Ungors, or a band of @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-dslf.actors.Actor.xOMceDSC4pxIjQcR]{Outlaws}.

results.1-5: Wilderness Event. Roll on the @Table[wilderness-travel-events]{Wilderness Travel Events Table 1 - Light Woodland, Hills and Temperate Plains}.
results.6-6: Mountain Sickness. This sometimes afflicts those travelling at high altitudes before they can get used to the lack of oxygen in the air. Characters should make a Challenging (+0) Endurance or be subject to @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-dslf.items.Item.b9CyizYEyH9wjY9p]{Mountain Sickness}. Ogres, Dwarfs, and animals that are used to life at high altitude do not need to test for Mountain Sickness.
results.7-7: Scree Slope. The Characters path is blocked by a steep slope of small loose stones. They can either cross or add two stages to the journey. If they cross each member must pass a Challenging (+0) Athletics. Those who fail suffer a fall of [[/r 1d10]] yards. Quadrupeds, such as mounts and pack animals, benefit from +2 SL when taking this test.
results.8-8: Blizzard. The weather changes dramatically for the worse. Refer to the @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-dslf.journals.JournalEntry.xq3g1ukhk4RFHNSF.JournalEntryPage.yLVf0rmOShW3kqFI]{Weather Rules} and apply the following factors: Temperature: Bitter, Precipitation: Very Heavy, Visibility: Thick Fog, Wind: Very Strong. Once the stage is complete reroll the weather conditions as the blizzard abates.
results.9-9:
Beast Lair. The Characters come across the lair of a monstrous beast. In the mountains of the Reikland this is likely to be a Griffon, but it may be a Manticore, Pegasus, or Wyvern. Roll [[/r 1d10]].

  • 1–3: The beast is home and possesses the Territorial Trait, it will attack the Characters as long as they are within 50 yards of the lair.
  • 4–5: The beast is starving, reduce Strength and Toughness by 20, all other Characteristics by 10, and Wounds by [[/r 3d10]].
  • 6–7: The beast is home and will fight Characters to the death.
  • 8–9: The beast is absent, but in each round, there is a 3% chance that it will return.
  • 10: The beast is absent.

To determine whether there is anything of value in the lair roll twice on the loot column of the @Table[ancient-tomb]{Ancient Tomb Table}.
results.10-10: Enemies Encountered. A small group of enemies crosses the Characters’ path. In the mountains of the Reikland suitable enemies may be tribes of Orcs and Goblins, a band of Outlaws, or a pair of Stone Trolls.

results.1-5: Wilderness Event. Roll on the @Table[wilderness-travel-events]{Wilderness Travel Events Table 1 - Light Woodland, Hills and Temperate Plains}.
results.6-6: Swamp Fever. This is transmitted by bites from creatures like bog leeches and sea slugs. The bites often go unnoticed, especially when the victim is wading through murky swamp water. The disease is characterised by a painful, raw, red patch around the bite and sudden bouts of @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-dslf.items.Item.mr0lSbpT4bHhXycF]{Swamp Fever}.
results.7-7: Quick Mud. The area of the swamp is particularly treacherous, with soft mud flats that threaten to engulf any travellers who stray into it. The Characters can either skirt the mudflats by adding two stages to their journey, or risk crossing them. To cross the mudflats each Character and accompanying animal must make an Extended Challenging (+0) Strength to a total of 15 SL. If any fumbles are generated in the test the Character in question must test for @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.journals.JournalEntry.NS3YGlJQxwTggjRX.JournalEntryPage.WCivInLZrqEtZzF4#drowning-and-suffocation]{Suffocation} and start the process from the start to escape the mud flats. Characters may only assist their companions in these tests if they have already escaped the hazard.
results.8-8: Foul Air. The Characters wander into an area of suffocating gas. The gas pocket is [[/r 2d10]] yards long and anyone crossing must make an Average (+20) Endurance each turn or suffer the effects. This is like becoming drunk, so refer to the rules for @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.Item.R2ytluHiEFF2KQ5e]{Consume Alcohol}, (though it is the Endurance Test, rather than a Consume Alcohol Test, that must be passed to avoid impairment). If a Character passes out within the gas pocket they must be rescued or succumb to the gas and die in TB rounds. A point of Resilience may be spent in order to escape the gas pocket. Once free of the area an Average (+20) Endurance may be made every 5 minutes: the effects wear off once this test is passed. There is no hangover.
results.9-9: Beast Lair. The Characters come across the lair of a monstrous beast.
results.10-10: Enemies Encountered. A small group of enemies crosses the Characters’ path. In the wetlands of the Reikland, suitable enemies may be a band of six Goblins, a pair of River Trolls, or a band of three Fimir.

Willingness to Take a Bribe — Integrity.name: Willingness to Take a Bribe — Integrity

Willingness to Take a Bribe — Price.name: Willingness to Take a Bribe — Price

results.3-8:
Trivial: Status
Moderate: Status times 3
Serious: Status times 5
Henious: Will not take bribes
results.9-10:
Trivial: Status
Moderate: Status times 2
Serious: Status times 4
Henious: Status times 10
